723046f-a.title: Manhattan: Edgecombe Avenue - Jumel Terrace
723046f-a.text:
Roger Morris Park: The Jumel Mansion located in this
open area bounded by Edgecombe Avenue and Jumel Terrace,
between West 160th and 162nd Streets. This was Washing-
ton Headquarters in the Revolutionary War and is near
Fort George.
Prior to 1900

719628f-a.title: Manhattan: Edgecombe Avenue - Jumel Terrace
719628f-a.text:
M0RNI3-JU4L 1VNSIC: Rest 160th Street and Jumel lerrace, Man-
hattan. This heorgian structure was built as a country
estate 1n 1765 bg Roger orris, a wealthy merchant
Loyalst who returned to Ingland in 177G. It served
successively as headquarters for 6eneral Washington and
the British-hessian forces. After the war it was sold
for a tavern and used as a stop-off point by Soston-New
York stage coaches. It was bought in 1S10 by Stephen
Jumel, a .ine merchant, for his wife.
Bank ofNew York Calendar 1967-63

720720f-a.text:
46 Jumel Place, a two-story frame house adjoining the S.W. corner of
Edgecombe Avenue.
1932.

Negative No. 458.

723047f-b.title: Manhattan: Edgecombe Avenue - Jumel Terrace
723047f-b.text:
(1)
Roger Morris Park, Edgecombe Ave., west to Jumel Terrace and
West 160th to 162nd Streets. Building shown, is the Jumel Mansion
(1765). For further views see Edgecombe Ave.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 61O.
